â€¦Top peacekeeping officials recently completed a strategic review that highlights the #Darfur missionâ€™s shortcomings, including a reluctance to confront challenges and a deep pessimism over the missionâ€™s feasibility. Deliberations at the U.N. over its findings come as Foreign Policy has been publishing a trove of internal #UNAMID documents highlighting the blue helmetsâ€™ struggles to protect civilians. But the U.N. Security Council appears unlikely to shutter the $1.3 billion-a-year mission and declare defeat, reasoning that even a weak mission still provides some measure of deterrence against attacks on civilians.

â€œRichard Gowan, an expert on U.N. peacekeeping at New York Universityâ€™s Center for International Cooperation, recalled an argument he had with a U.N. official about Darfur. â€œI said this situation has become so bad and in many ways is such a disgrace that this is one case where the U.N. should declare defeat and go home,â€ Gowan said. â€œThe response from the U.N. colleague was that â€˜we would love to declare defeat but we canâ€™t. We have to accept this as a quagmire.â€™ There is a very strong sense within the U.N. that this was a mission that was set up to failâ€¦.â€
